Award.AwardTitle: Reproductive isolation, asynchrony, and incompatibility in fragmented prairie populations of Echinacea angustifolia
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability of organisms to successfully reproduce in small, isolated populations is a key factor in the generation and maintenance of biological diversity. Reproductive failure due to isolation is a current prospect for many of the long-lived, perennial plants that make up most of the grasslands of the central U.S. because these grasslands now exist mainly as small remnants of a once great prairie. Previous research has suggested that three of the most important causes of reproductive failure in prairie plants are mismatches in the timing of flowering, limited ability to disperse pollen, and mechanisms of compatibility that restrict mating between closely related individuals. This project will be the first to test how all three of these factors operate together in a natural system. Researchers will measure timing and compatibility of plants of Echinacea angustifolia (coneflowers) in 27 populations in Minnesota over three years and merge these data with an 18-year, continuing study on the population growth of the species. The intended result is a unified understanding of how habitat fragmentation affects the reproductive potential of grassland plants.

The broader impacts of this project include conservation of biodiversity, student training, and new tools for the scientific community. Results will be communicated to land managers and the general public through the outreach programs and collaborations of the Chicago Botanical Garden. Baccalaureate and graduate students will learn new skills in population biology and computing. The project will publish its detailed spatial and temporal data sets of reproduction in Echinacea and develop freely available software to enable other researchers to manage, visualize, and analyze this information in Echinacea and other species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Reproduction is essential for organisms to persist in small, isolated populations. Many of the long-lived, perennial plants that make up the grasslands of central North America face reproductive failure because these grasslands now exist mainly as small remnants of a once vast prairie and plants are isolated from potential mates. Previous research identified three important causes of reproductive failure in prairie plants: plants are too far from potential mates, they flower at a different time from potential mates, and they are incompatible partners with potential mates. For this project, we investigated how all three of these issues interact in natural conditions using a model organism for perennial prairie plants, Echinacea angustifolia, a purple coneflower native to the U.S west of the Mississippi River.

During four summers, we mapped several thousand flowering coneflower plants in 27 populations in Minnesota and determined the first and last day of flowering of each plant. We also assessed mating compatibility among several hundred pairs of plants and quantified seed production, a measure of reproductive success, in over a hundred plants each year. We merged this dataset with data from an ongoing study of this species that started in 1995. Results of the present study, including the datasets, methods used to visualize and analyze the data, and key findings have contributed to a more unified understanding of how habitat fragmentation affects the reproductive potential of perennial plants. These results are important for helping scientists to learn how fragmentation affects reproductions in organisms worldwide and for helping land managers to improve and maintain healthy prairies. We have shared our findings with other scientists, land stewards, managers, practitioners, and policymakers at conferences, in workshops, and through publication in journals. Here are four key findings:

1. Timing of flowering is very important to mating. We found that the days that a plant flowers within a season affects its mating opportunities. Timing also matters from year to year. Plants do not flower every year and the number of plants flowering each year varies substantially over our 11-year study period. Flowering in peak years increases mating opportunities. We found that timing among years matters 39% more to mating opportunities than timing within years.

2. The timing of flowering within seasons is inherited by offspring from parents. Even though timing varies due to weather and other environmental circumstances over our experimental years (2005, '06, '15, and '16), we attributed about 30% of the variation to additive genes, the genetic variation that responds to natural selection. The remaining ~70% results from the environment and other genes.

3. Pollinator visitation to Echinacea changes substantially through the flowering season. Visitation rates decrease through the season, the species of bees changes, and the amount of Echinacea pollen on bees decreases. This is important because natural selection for early flowering is widely observed across diverse plants species. However, the role of pollinators as agents of selection has rarely been investigated in realistic conditions, especially with solitary bees or in perennial plants.

4. Fire plays a big role in mating opportunities and reproduction. In our model prairie plant, fires synchronize reproduction, leading to increased mating opportunities and improved reproduction. Fires synchronize flowering both within and among years, increasing seed production 88% after fire. These findings demonstrate a novel and potentially widespread mechanism by which fire can enhance plant reproduction, promote population growth, and maintain plant diversity in fire-dependent ecosystems worldwide. This is important because reduced fire frequency in the North American prairie is contributing to local plant extinctions.

While making our major findings, we developed software for managing, visualizing, and analyzing spatially and temporally explicit datasets of mating potential. This software package, called “mateable” is open source and freely available as part of the statistical program, R. It is invaluable to our team and other research scientists are beginning to use this tool.

We have also trained scientists and educators. We employed five interns and six graduate students, providing training and professional development. We also utilized REU, RET, ROA, and RAHSS supplemental funds from NSF to support career exploration, advancement, training, and professional development for a high school teacher, six college students, two high school students, and one college faculty member. Many others participated in this project, including a dedicated corps of 18 citizen scientists. Everyone learned science by doing it and they helped advance understanding of biology and conservation of long-lived herbaceous plants.

We maintain a website (http://echinaceaProject.org/) to disseminate results and organize datasets. The website provides information on how to improve the conservation and management of perennial populations in fragmented habitat. In addition, the website furthers our educational goals. We also keep project members, collaborators, and the public up-to-date on lab and field activities with a blog, Facebook, and Twitter (@TeamEchinacea).
